docs.text: Welcome to my wesbite. ¶ I’m Hannah Peevey, currently pursuing my Master’s in Design for Emergent Futures at the Institute for Advanced Architecture of Catalonia (IAAC). Through the MDEF program, I’m seeking to develop a framework that brings structure to my creative practice and helps me translate imaginative concepts into tangible realities. My background is in Architecture and Design, which has fundamentally reshaped how I perceive and experience the world. Design has expanded my understanding of how our surroundings influence daily life — and how thoughtful creation can reimagine those interactions. I’m driven to challenge the boundaries of sustainable design and explore innovative solutions that enhance everyday experiences through spaces, objects, and systems
docs.title: Home

docs.text: Term 2 ¶ MDEF Term 1 What is going on!!!!!! This term focuses on xxx 🟡 Studio 0 ¶ Project 1 - Design Bet ¶ On our first week of MDEF we were asked “What is your research interest?” I found this question to be equally as scary as someone asking you “what do you want to be when you grow up?”, “who are you as a designer?”,”why dont you use your architecture degree?” What did I do I went through my six essays I had written when applying to multiple graduate schools and , with the help of chat gbt, I found one common denominator. TO SHAPE THE HUMAN EXPERIENCE TO SHAPE THE HUMAN EXPERIENCE - Creating moments that often go unnoticed yet define the quality of our lives - experiences that linger - a space, a texture, or an interaction that feels personal and alive - “To make invisible data visible again.” 🟣 Project 2 — Algorithmic Mood Predictor ¶ Description: A playful Google Sheets experiment that predicts your emotional state based on your daily inputs (sleep, caffeine, steps, screen time, cycle phase, and mood word). Goal: To show how much emotional power we give to algorithms. Tools: Google Sheets, Formulas, Conditional Logic, Data Visualization 🟢 Project 3 — Digital Confession Archive ¶ Idea: Collected confessions from strangers were printed and scattered around Barcelona — reconnecting the digital and physical layers of data. Outcome: A growing physical archive of digital intimacy. 🧭 Reflection ¶ Through these prototypes, I explored how digital systems shape emotional transparency — asking where the line between comfort and exposure lies. Next, I aim to connect this to wearable design and sensor-based interaction for my master project. Last updated: November 2025
docs.title: Term 1
